title: The Rainbow Explosion Is the ‘It Cake’ of Social Media. It Doesn’t Work.
text:
Daniella Da Silva made her first attempt last year at the trendy cake that is sweeping Instagram: a confection dubbed the “rainbow explosion cake,” whose sprinkle-filled center is supposed to unleash a cascade of colorful tiny candies when sliced open. She was eager to see her friends’ reaction. But the big moment underwhelmed: The sprinkles merely trickled down. “It was a little bit of a letdown,” says Ms. Da Silva.

Since then she has learned to cut a larger hole to create a more dramatic sprinkle outflow. She is careful with the terminology too. Calling it an explosion cake creates confusion: “I have to reassure everyone that their cake will not actually explode,” she says. Instead she calls it a piñata cake to “manage expectations,” she says.

Ms. Da Silva is one of many bakers grappling with the challenges of today’s social media It cake, whose TV and internet stardom has inspired home chefs. The cake been featured on the “Today” show, Rachael Ray and made several appearances on Kim Kardashian’s Instagram account.

The cake’s signature feature is a hollowed out center filled with sprinkles. When it’s sliced open, the stack of sprinkles pours out. But for some home chefs, it can seem like less of an explosion and more of a gentle trickle.

“It’s pretty dull from a flair perspective. It really doesn’t have that big of a wow factor when you think about it,” says Sean Coary, assistant professor of food marketing at St. Joseph’s University in Philadelphia.

Still, many home bakers are eager to give it a try. This May, Williams Sonoma started selling the Flour Shop Rainbow Explosion Cake Kit. The mix has become Williams Sonoma’s best-selling cake kit, the company says. Components include food coloring, cake mix, sprinkles and instructions for baking a rainbow-colored six-tiered cake; the kit is sold in a nontoxic paint can. “If you don’t know about this cake and you bring this thing out, people’s jaws just drop—it’s been exciting,” says Neil Lick, the store’s vice president of food, books and the test kitchen in San Francisco. Some stores sold out of the kit completely and are hosting baking workshops for customers. A Christmas-themed version and more branded accessories are launching later this year, adds Mr. Lick.

The company developed the product after working for more than a year with Amirah Kassem, owner of Flour Shop bakery in New York. Ms. Kassem helped popularize the cake on social media and is credited with inventing the term “rainbow explosion.” “It’s an explosion of fun—no one thinks the cakes explode,” she says.

Williams Sonoma sells a Flour Shop Rainbow Explosion Cake Kit, which includes food coloring, sprinkles and frosting mix. Photo: Williams Sonoma

“Amirah’s cake was an established, trademarked, highly coveted product and an internet sensation by the time we started producing the kit for it so there was no need to change the name and no customer has ever complained about it,” Williams Sonoma said in an emailed statement.

After Aideen Turner spent nearly three hours baking the cake from the Williams Sonoma kit in her Sea Isle City, N.J., vacation home for 16 children and their parents over Labor Day weekend, she asked family members to gather around for a surprise as she cut the cake. The guest who was least impressed? Her husband: “He said, ‘I thought something was actually going to jump out of it,’ ” says Ms. Turner, 49, who adds that it took three rounds of vacuuming to get rid of the fallen sprinkles.

The Flour Shop’s Ms. Kassem recommends several techniques to avoid an underwhelming sprinkle-trickle. She says the cascading effect increases when bakers build up a taller 6-inch round cake with a 1.5-inch hole in the center for the sprinkles—she suggests stacking four or more cake layers to maximize the outpour. “To get the insides to come out more, height is one of the big differentiators,” she says.

Chefs often experiment with different types of candy fillings in addition to sprinkles, but Ms. Kassem says not all of them work well. Gumballs can be a choking hazard for younger children and larger candies won’t pour out. “I can tell you from experience that cereal is not good and marshmallows are not good, because they get stuck together,” adds Ms. Kassem.

At General Mills , a Betty Crocker recipe for a “rainbow-surprise-inside cake” deliberately avoids the word explosion. “It sounds like it’s dangerous,” says Cathy Swanson Wheaton, executive editor for Betty Crocker and Pillsbury Cookbooks at General Mills Inc. The company “takes a cautious approach, so we chose to focus on the surprise element instead of explosions,” she adds. Page views for its 2014 recipe, which calls for sprinkles and M&Ms, increased 38% last year.

Bakers must guard against setting off the big moment prematurely. After using a Betty Crocker recipe to bake a sprinkles cake at her granddaughter Ella’s request last year, university professor Carol Simon hopped into a taxi to hand deliver the cake to the science-themed birthday party. When the driver hit the brakes, her rainbow-colored masterpiece “had the explosion,” said Ms. Simon. Having spent hours on research and baking, Ms. Simon decided to bring the smashed cake anyway. “It looked disastrous and the 4-year-olds had a meltdown,” she says.

Share Your Thoughts Is social media ruining cake? Join the conversation below.

Some bakers manage to achieve success. When Melanie Berg’s best friend asked her to create a wedding cake in a pinch two years ago, she obliged. Inspired by an online video, the 29-year-old carved out the circular center of a tiered white cake. She poured rainbow sprinkles into the center and sealed it with a layer of cake and frosting.

The wedding cake Melanie Berg made for her best friend featured sprinkles that poured out. Photo: Chris and Kira Photography

After 200 guests gathered to watch the couple take the first bite, the sprinkles poured out. “Everyone was kind of speechless and asking how I did it,” says Ms. Berg. The Chattanooga-based adolescent addiction counselor has since launched a baking side gig.

For those tired of dealing with tiny sprinkles, Mr. Coary, the food marketing professor, says not to worry. He predicts the rainbow explosion cake will soon be supplanted by other social-media fueled trends. There’s the “geode,” a cake that looks like it’s filled with sparkling crystals, and the “fault line,” which is designed with a crack to reveal the interior of the cake, may soon dominate social-media baking trends. As for the rainbow explosion, he says, “it will go away just like the cronut did.”
